results.title: Thailand
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission, Film Australia, University of Queensland, John Temple, Don Murray, Roan Hannam and Arch Nicholson
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Asian insight”
A look at the historical and cultural background of Thailand. Focuses on the respect the Thais have for the monks and their religion, and the veneration of the monarchy.

results.title: Thai Airways fly 748
results.creator_credit: Technical and Scientific Films, British Information Services and Paul Cullerne
results.brief_description: The British Hawker 748 seen in daily scheduled operation with Thai Airways against the spectacular scenery and colourful background of Thailand. The aircraft are seen in service on Thailand’s internal routes and in production at Manchester. Features of the aircraft are explained and its ease of servicing illustrated.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Technical and Scientific Films, British Information Services and Paul Cullerne

results.title: Tgv, Ariane
results.brief_description:
The first segment explores the Ariane launching centre in Kourou (Fr. Guyanna). The second segment takes us on board a high-speed train on the day a speed record of 380 km/h is established.

Credits: No credits available.

results.title: Textures
results.brief_description: Explores the factors which influence our impression of texture: light, point of view and function. Visual examples range from Henry Moore’s sculptures to simple kitchen utensils. Combines a sensitive use of close-up photography with a percussion score by Herb Harris. No other credtits available.

results.title: Texture in painting
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the significance of texture in painting and in everyday life. Painters Phoebe Flory and Eliot O’Hara explain the thinking behind the use of textures, with illustrative examples that span the history of art from the Ming Dynasty to today’s non-objective painters.
results.description: Demonstrates the significance of texture in painting and in everyday life. Painters Phoebe Flory and Eliot O’Hara explain the thinking behind the use of textures, with illustrative examples that span the history of art from the Ming Dynasty to today’s non-objective painters.

results.title: Texture (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Paul Burnford
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Art in Action”
Studies in hard, rough, soft, smooth surfaces provide a tangible approach to understanding textural qualities in art. Points out the various textural effects which can be achieved with clay, metals, paper, linoleum, and other art materials.

results.title: Textiles and ornamental arts of India
results.creator_credit: Eames, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Charles Eames and Ray Eames
results.brief_description: Displays the variety, sophistication, and beauty of India’s textiles and ornamental arts in a unique filmic interpretation of a exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in New York City. Captures the flavour of Indian traditions and philosophy, and explores the spiritual significance of art in the everyday life of the Indian people.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Eames, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Charles Eames and Ray Eames

results.title: Textiles
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional and John C. Elder
results.brief_description: A comprehensive survey of the Scottish textile industry, showing the relation between the centres of the various industries and the resources of raw materials and driving-power for the mills. The process of manufacture of tweeds, linen, sailcloth from jute, and cotton and silk thread are shown in detail.
results.description: A comprehensive survey of the Scottish textile industry, showing the relation between the centres of the various industries and the resources of raw materials and driving-power for the mills. The process of manufacture of tweeds, linen, sailcloth from jute, and cotton and silk thread are shown in detail.

results.title: Text rain
results.brief_description: TEXT RAIN is a playful interactive installation that blurs the boundary between the familiar and the magical. Participants in TEXT RAIN installation use familiar instruments of their bodies, to do what seems magical - to lift and play with falling letters that do not really exist. In the TEXT RAIN installation participants stand or move in front of a large projection screen. On the screen they see a mirrored video projection of themselves in black and white, combined with colour animation of falling text. Like rain or snow, the text appears to land on the participants heads and arms. The text responds to the participants mentions and can be caught, lifted, and then let fall again. The falling text will land on anything darker than a certain threshold, and fall whenever that obstacle is removed.

results.title: Texasville
results.creator_credit: Nelson Entertainment, Cine-Source, Barry Spikings and Peter Bogdanovich
results.brief_description: Twenty years after his acclaimed “The Last Picture Show”, Peter Bogdanovich returns to the small town of Texasville to investigate what happened to the characters who inhabited the initial film. Duane (Jeff Bridges) is now an oil businessman whose company is going broke and his marriage to the vivacious Karla (Annie Potts) is on the rocks. A chance encounter with his old high school flame Jayce (Cybil Shepherd) precipitates a mid-life crisis for Duane and he begins to question his philandering and his refusal to let go of the past. The performances are what makes this film wonderful, with excellent performances by the entire cast. Engaging and humane, “Texasville” is a bittersweet elegy to growing old and the slowly extinguishing values of small-town life. Based on the novel by Larry McMurty.
